title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. Amendments to Public Law 93-100 state that no institution prohibited by law can offer demand deposit accounts. The amendments will take effect two years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of Prohibition on Payment of Interest on Demand Deposits, joint rulemaking required for authorization of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions. Regulations required for authorization of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions must establish scope, types of accounts, limitations, exceptions, and restrictions. Effective date of regulations is within 2 years of enactment. Definitions include terms like "depository institution," "transaction account," and "Federal banking agency." The amendments made by subsection (a) of the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act will become effective within 2 years of enactment or when final regulations are issued. SEC. 4. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks is amended to allow balances maintained by depository institutions to receive earnings at a rate not exceeding short-term interest rates, to be paid quarterly. The Board may regulate the payment and distribution of these earnings to the maintaining institutions. The amendment allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at Federal Reserve Banks, with regulations on the distribution of earnings to these institutions. The term 'depository institution' includes trust companies, corporations organized under specific sections, and branches or agencies. The amendment expands the definition of depository institutions to include trust companies, corporations organized under specific sections, and branches or agencies of foreign banks. Amendments are made to the Federal Reserve Act regarding pass-through reserves for member banks and technical and conforming amendments. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than 8 percent (including zero). SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts for real estate transactions, excluding certain activities from being considered as interest payments under various laws. The text discusses the treatment of escrow accounts in real estate transactions, including forbearance from charging fees and benefits accruing to the account holder.
